ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: Do you build a tower on every hilltop, just to amuse yourselves,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: You construct monuments on every hill in vain,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: What, you build a monument on every hill merely for fun
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Do you build useless monuments on every mountain
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: “What! You build a structure on every height, to laugh at the passers-by?”
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Do you build on every Ri` an Ayah for your amusement"
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Do you build on every height a monument? Vain is it that you do:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: What, do you build on every prominence a sign, sporting,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: Build ye on every high place a monument for vain delight?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: Do you build monuments on every high place in vanity,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Build ye on every eminence a landmark in vanity?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: Do you build futile a sign on every prominence?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Do ye build a landmark on every high place to amuse yourselves?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Do you build high palaces on every high place, while you do not live in them?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: Do you build over each high place a sign to amuse yourselves!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Do you build a monument on every height for vanity's sake?
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Do you construct on every elevation a sign, amusing yourselves,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [26:128] Do you build on every prominence, every high place, a monument, an edifice as a signpost for passers-by, so that you may hurl abuse?, at those who pass by you and deride them (ta‘bathūna, is a circumstantial qualifier referring to the subject of [the verb] tabnūna, ‘you build’).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: 416 Build ye on every high place a monument for vain delight?) you beat up any stranger who passes by you and steal his clothes; this can also be understood in this manner: do you build in every marketplace a sign by means of which you scoff at whoever passes by you?
